column1: Toms River is a township in Ocean County
column2: New Jersey
column3: United States. Its mainland portion is also a census-designated place of the same name
column4: which serves as the county seat of Ocean County. Formerly known as the Township of Dover
column5: in 2006 voters approved a change of the official name to the Township of Toms River
column6: adopting the name of the largest unincorporated community within the township. As of the 2010 United States Census
column7: the township had a total population of 91
column9: with the township ranking as the 8th-most-populous municipality in the state in 2010 (after having been ranked 7th in 2000) and the second most-populous municipality in Ocean County (behind Lakewood Township
column14: which had in turn increased by 13
column17: Toms River was ranked by Morgan Quitno Press as the 15th safest city in the United States
column19: Toms River was again ranked as the 14th-safest city in the United States of 371 cities nationwide.Toms River can be seen in various TV and news media including MTV's Made and Jersey Shore (seasons 1
column22: HBO's Boardwalk Empire and the original The Amityville Horror movie. In 1998
column23: Toms River East Little League won the Little League World Series. The township has what is said to be the second-largest Halloween parade in the world.

column1: Much of the early history of the settlement of Toms River is obscured by conflicting stories. Various sources list the eponym of the township as either English captain William Tom
column2: farmer and ferryman Thomas Luker
column3: or a Native American named Tom. In 1992
column4: as part of celebrations commemorating the township's 225th anniversary
column5: official recognition was granted to the tradition that the "Tom" in "Toms River" was for Thomas Luker
column6: who ran a ferry across Goose Creek (now the Toms River). During the 19th century
column7: Toms River became a center for shipbuilding
column10: and iron and lumber production. The settlement and the river were usually spelled "Tom's River" in its early days
column11: though its current spelling has been standard since the middle of the 19th century.

column1: Toms River was located in the southern section of the Township of Shrewsbury that obtained a royal charter to secede in 1767 and form Dover Township.  During the American Revolutionary War
column2: Toms River was home to a strategically important salt works that supplied colonial militias
column3: as well as a base for privateer vessels that plundered British and Tory ships off the coast.  In March 1782
column4: a group of British and loyalist soldiers attacked a blockhouse along the river that housed the colonial militia and captured Captain Joshua Huddy
column5: who was later hanged at Sandy Hook.  Also destroyed were the salt works and most of the houses in the village. The incident greatly complicated the tense relationship between the British
column6: loyalist
column7: and colonial and was a factor in prolonging the peace negotiations that were then in progress in Paris until 1783.The village of Toms River is listed on both the national and state registers of historic places.Dover Township was incorporated as one of New Jersey's first 104 townships by the Township Act of 1798 of the New Jersey Legislature on February 21
column8: 1798. Portions of the township were taken to form Jackson Township (March 6
column23: 1913). The township's original name was for Dover
column25: and was changed to Toms River Township based on a referendum passed in 2006.

column2: Toms River became the county seat of the newly created Ocean County when it was formed out of southern Monmouth County. During the second half of the 19th century and the early decades of the 20th
column3: many new towns were carved out of Dover Township
column4: including Brick
column5: Jackson
column6: Lakewood and Berkeley. The Village of Toms River attempted twice—in 1914 and 1926—to secede from Dover Township
column7: but residents were unsuccessful. The part of Toms River on the south side of the river stretching down to Berkeley Township incorporated as South Toms River in 1927
column8: but the core of the original village on the north side remains part of the wider township to this day.

column1: In the last two decades of the twentieth century
column2: the demographics of the township changed substantially
column3: adding over 20
column4: 000 residents just in the 1990s. While the village is still the center of municipal and county government
column5: the population in the area exploded in the decades after World War II
column6: due in part to the completion of the Garden State Parkway. Whereas the village was the largest and most densely populated section of the township for over two centuries
column7: the vast majority of residents now shop and work in other sections of the town.

column1: Toms River made international headlines in the 1990s with their Little League Baseball team
column2: nicknamed "Beast from the East"
column3: which competed in the Little League World Series three times in five years
column4: winning in 1998 when they defeated Japan by a score of 12–9. More than 40
column5: 000 people lined Route 37 for a parade following their victory over Kashima
column6: Japan. Toms River Little League made it to Williamsport in 2010 giving Toms River its record fourth Mid-Atlantic championship.

column1: Toms River is also home to many National Champion Pop Warner Football and Cheerleading titles. 1996 Toms River Raider Jr. PeeWee Football team won a National Championship. Cheerleaders from the Toms River Little Indians
column2: Toms River Raiders
column3: and the Toms River Angels (formerly the Saint Joe's Angels) have won many National Titles. The first National Championship title was won in 1993 by the Toms River Little Indian Midget Cheer squad. In 2001
column5: and 2003 the Toms River Angels brought home national titles resulting in the nations second ever three peat (meaning they brought home three national titles on the same level). In 2005
column6: The Toms River Little Indians brought home two more national titles
column7: and the Toms River Raiders won one. In 2006
column8: The Toms River Angels Midget Large Advanced Cheer Squad and the Toms River Little Indians Midget Small Intermediate Cheer Squad won two more National Titles.  In 2007 The Toms River Angels brought home one and the Indians brought back two more to add to their history.

column2: state and federal health and environmental agencies identified an increased incidence of childhood cancers in Toms River from the 1970–1995 period.  Multiple investigations by state and federal environmental and health agencies indicated that the likely source of the increased cancer risk was contamination from Toms River Chemical Plant (then operated by Ciba-Geigy)
column3: which had been in operation since 1952.  The area was designated a United States Environmental Protection Agency Superfund site in 1983 after an underground plume of toxic chemicals was identified.  The following year
column4: a discharge pipe was shut down after a sinkhole at the corner of Bay Avenue and Vaughn Avenue revealed that it had been leaking.  The plant ceased operation in 1996. A follow up study from the 1996–2000 period indicated that while there were more cancer cases than expected
column5: rates had significantly fallen and the difference was statistically insignificant compared to normal statewide cancer rates. Since 1996
column6: the Toms River water system has been subject to the most stringent water testing in the state and is considered safe for consumption. Dan Fagin's Toms River: A Story of Science and Salvation
column7: the 2014 Pulitzer Prize winning book
column8: examined the issue of industrial pollution in detail.

column1: Toms River at one time referred only to the rural farming community of Toms River
column2: a small part of the vast Township of Dover that included several other distinct settlements. With the United States Postal Service's adoption of Toms River mailing addresses for Dover Township
column3: coupled with demographic changes in the other sections
column4: those inside and outside began referring to all of mainland Dover Township as Toms River. In the 1990 Census
column5: the census-designated place called "Toms River" only included the downtown village area that included fewer than 8
column6: 000 residents in 1990.  Due to complaints of confusion
column7: the CDP was broadened to include all of mainland Dover Township to better reflect the more common usage for the area.Over the years
column8: confusion over the name of the township had become an issue for many residents.  A movement organized around the Dover Township Name Change Committee
column9: founded by Mayor Paul Brush and supported by the Ocean County Chamber of Commerce
column10: collected signatures to put a name change question on the ballot in November 2006. On Election Day
column13: over 60% of residents voted to approve changing the name from the Township of Dover to the Township of Toms River. The name change campaign featured the slogan "Toms River YES"
column14: signifying a yes vote for the name change
column15: and the name was officially changed on November 14

column1: Toms River has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen: Cfa)
column2: although it can be described as a hot-summer humid continental climate (Dfa) by the 0 °C isotherm because January averages are lower than New York City
column3: even being about 50 miles to the north. The township was severely affected by the damage brought by Hurricane Sandy in October 2012. Many low-lying areas of the township
column4: including Silverton and the downtown area
column5: saw their worst flooding ever when the storm surge overwhelmed the Barnegat Bay up and down the Jersey Shore. The barrier islands
column6: just across the bridge
column7: suffered even worse devastation from the storm surge brought by the hurricane. Extremes range from a record high of 105 °F on both July 19
column9: 1896 to a low of -24 °F on January 16

column1: Toms River has many shopping malls including Ocean County Mall (the only enclosed mall in Ocean County) and Seacourt Pavilion
column2: located across Bay Avenue from the Ocean County Mall. It is home to the corporate headquarters of EGM Green

column9: 000 attendees at the 2008 event.Joshua Huddy Park is located in Downtown Toms River and is host to a replica constructed in 1931 of the Revolutionary War fort that was once standing near the site. The town played host to a short skirmish during the Revolution in which Captain Joshua Huddy was captured by a group of Loyalists while defending the Toms River Blockhouse and hanged without trial. The trail of Captain Huddy can be followed throughout the town.

column1: The John Bennett Indoor Athletic Complex is the only indoor athletic complex bubble in Ocean County and one of the largest in New Jersey. It was severely damaged as a result of Hurricane Sandy

Toms River Township has operated within the Faulkner Act (formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law) under the Mayor-Council form of New Jersey municipal government. The township is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and seven-member Township Council. The council includes four members who each represent one of four wards of the township and three who are chosen at-large. The mayor and the seven council members are chosen on a partisan basis as part of the November general election in odd-numbered years to serve four-year terms of office on a staggered basis
column3: with the mayor and three at-large seats elected together and the four ward seats chosen simultaneously two years later.As of 2020

column5: whose term of office expires December 31
column6: 2023. Township Council members are Kevin Geoghegan (R

column1: Students in pre-kindergarten through twelfth grade attend the Toms River Regional Schools
column2: a regional public school system (centered primarily in Toms River Township) that is the largest suburban school district in New Jersey. In addition to students from Toms River
column3: the district also serves the adjoining boroughs of Beachwood
column4: Pine Beach and South Toms River. It is the largest suburban school district in the state
column5: and the fourth largest school district in New Jersey (after Newark
column6: Jersey City and Paterson). It is also the largest school district in the state that is not an Abbott District. As of the 2018–19 school year

It's associated with both the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools and the Association of Christian Schools International.

column1: Two of the most congested roads are Hooper Avenue and Route 37. Route 37 sees extra traffic from travelers to the Jersey shore during the summertime

This project was killed in 1980.

column1: Toms River gained some notoriety in 1984 when local businessman Robert O. Marshall was charged with (and later convicted of) the contract killing of his wife

column4: Blind Faith
